The '''klibc''' is a minimalistic [[C standard library|libc]] subset developed by [[Peter Anvin|H. Peter Anvin]], intended to be used within an [[initramfs]], as part of a multi-stage [[Linux]] boot process. It is incorporated by default into initial ram filesystems that are created by the mkinitramfs script in [[Debian]] and [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]]. Further more it has a set of small unix utilities that are useful in early userspace (cpio, dash, fstype, mkdir, [[mknod]], mount, nfsmount, run-init, ..).
+
The '''klibc''' is a minimalistic [[C standard library|libc]] subset developed by [[Peter Anvin|H. Peter Anvin]], intended to be used within an [[initramfs]], as part of a multi-stage [[Linux]] boot process. It is incorporated by default into initial ram filesystems that are created by the mkinitramfs script in [[Debian]] and [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]]. Further more it has a set of small unix utilities that are useful in early userspace (cpio, dash, fstype, mkdir, [[mknod]], mount, nfsmount, run-init, ..).
The klibc effort states as goal to move as much initialization code in Linux as possible out of the kernel<ref>{{cite web |url=http://marc.info/?l=linux-kernel&m=103622506919278&w=2 |title=initramfs merge, part 1 of N |date=[[2002-02-11]] }}</ref>: "some initialization is better done in user space" <ref>{{cite web |url= http://marc.info/?l=linux-kernel&m=103626389507412&w=2 |title= Re: initramfs merge, part 1 of N |date=[[2002-02-11]] }}</ref>
The klibc effort states as goal to move as much initialization code in Linux as possible out of the kernel<ref>{{cite web |url=http://marc.info/?l=linux-kernel&m=103622506919278&w=2 |title=initramfs merge, part 1 of N |date=[[2002-02-11]] }}</ref>: "some initialization is better done in user space" <ref>{{cite web |url= http://marc.info/?l=linux-kernel&m=103626389507412&w=2 |title= Re: initramfs merge, part 1 of N |date=[[2002-02-11]] }}</ref>
